article.title: Recognition of Blood Cancer Using Different Classification Techniques

choices: A blood smear showing signs of anemia.
A blood smear showing an abnormal proliferation of white blood cells, indicative of leukemia.
A blood smear showing a lack of red blood cells.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the IHS fusion method, what is replaced with the panchromatic image after the RGB to IHS transformation?
What does PCA stand for in the context of image fusion?
What does "GA" stand for in the context of leukemia image classification?
In the SSOCF crossover operator, what does "SSOCF" stand for?
What is the primary goal of the K-Means clustering algorithm?
choices: To identify outliers in a dataset.
To partition data points into K distinct clusters based on similarity.
To predict future data points based on existing patterns.
To reduce the dimensionality of a dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: What distinguishes the Manhattan distance from the Euclidean distance in measuring distance between data points?
choices: Manhattan distance is always shorter than Euclidean distance.
Manhattan distance calculates distance as movement along grid lines, while Euclidean distance calculates the straight-line distance.
Manhattan distance is only applicable in two dimensions, while Euclidean distance can be used in any number of dimensions.
There is no difference; both measures calculate distance in the same way.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between Fuzzy C-Means clustering and K-Means clustering?
choices: Fuzzy C-Means clustering can only handle numerical data, while K-Means clustering can handle both numerical and categorical data.
Fuzzy C-Means clustering allows for partial membership of data points to multiple clusters, while K-Means clustering assigns each data point to a single cluster.
Fuzzy C-Means clustering is deterministic, while K-Means clustering is stochastic.
Fuzzy C-Means clustering is computationally less expensive than K-Means clustering.
